awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4:@NASA: Automating Character Extraction for Taxonomic Species Descriptions Using Neural Networks, Transformer, and Computer Vision Signal Processing Architectures
awd_abstract_narration:
This project would provide a fellowship to an Associate professor and training for a graduate student at the University of Puerto Rico Mayaguez.  Arthropoda, a group that includes insects, spiders, and millipedes, is Earth's most diverse phylum with over 1.01 million known species. With an estimated 7 million species yet to be discovered, and a discovery rate of just 7,000 species per year, it would take around 850 years to identify them all, a process currently taking an average of 21 years per species. This project aims to expedite this through "Descriptron", a groundbreaking artificial intelligence tool leveraging machine learning and computer vision to accelerate species descriptions and taxonomic key generation.  In collaboration with NASA Marshall Space Flight Center, the project will utilize advanced imaging technology to automate the capture and description of arthropod morphological features, reducing human error and ensuring reproducible results. The implications extend across ecology, evolutionary biology, and developmental biology.  Emphasizing the role of citizen science, the project involves the wider community in data annotation via iNaturalist, fostering public participation in scientific discovery. This endeavor advances our understanding of biodiversity in our own backyards and accelerates the identification of undiscovered life on Earth.

Panarthropoda, encompassing Onychophora, Tardigrada, Chelicerata, Myriapoda, and Pancrustacea, is Earth's largest and most diverse clade, with an estimated 7 million species yet to be discovered. Through "Descriptron", an artificial intelligence (AI) pipeline, this project will significantly accelerate taxonomic species descriptions and key generation through the utilization of state-of-the-art transformers, convolutional neural networks, and computer vision techniques. Key to this endeavor is a strategic collaboration with NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center, providing advanced imaging technology for Descriptron's development. Advanced imaging techniques will greatly speed up the development of novel training data needed for the automation of instance segmentation and text description process of arthropod morphological features, reducing human error and ensuring highly reproducible, objective results. By creating a library of models for sclerites and descriptive terms including color, texture, and shape, Descriptron will automate the process of producing a skeletonized taxonomic species description.  This project leverages citizen science by engaging the broader community in the data annotation process via the iNaturalist platform. This approach not only facilitates public understanding and appreciation of biodiversity but also contributes essential data to the project. The use of Descriptron promises wide-reaching impacts across various fields such as ecology, evolutionary biology, and developmental biology that depend upon accurate morphological data. By effectively involving citizen scientists and accelerating taxonomic discovery, this project holds substantial potential to advance our understanding of Earth's biodiversity and expedite the biodiscovery process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to develop and test Descriptron, a new software application that uses artificial intelligence (AI) to automate the creation of taxonomic species descriptions. Taxonomy—the science of describing, classifying and naming Earth’s species—is a cornerstone of biology, yet it often proceeds slowly. Vast numbers of undescribed organisms are stored in research collections worldwide, and significant parts of the planet’s biodiversity remain unexplored. Descriptron helps address these issues by streamlining how biologists document the forms and features of organisms, thereby accelerating the discovery of new species.

Motivation and Significance
Traditional taxonomic description requires close attention to complex morphological details: shape, color, anatomical structures, and measurements must all be carefully captured and recorded. Although powerful image-processing tools are available, most demand a high level of specialized expertise and extensive coding skills. Furthermore, drafting a formal species description can be laborious, often taking weeks to years per species. Descriptron provides a more accessible pathway by integrating computer vision, deep learning, and large language models to automate much of the the species description process.

Research Objectives and Approach

1. Automated Morphological Analysis: We trained AI models (including cutting-edge vision transformers) to recognize and outline specific anatomical regions in specimen images. For example, Descriptron can detect wing veins, leg segments, or other identifying structures in insects—critical features that taxonomists often rely on.
2. Geometric Morphometrics: The software automatically extracts shape data (e.g., length, curvature, angles) from these outlined structures. Such quantitative measurements allow researchers to compare subtle morphological variations across specimens or species.
3. Color and Pattern Extraction: Descriptron characterizes color distributions, enabling comparisons that can reveal whether coloration patterns are species-specific.
4. Automated Draft Taxonomic Descriptions: Once Descriptron has collected the relevant shape and color data, Descriptron can talk to Large Language Models to generate an initial draft of the species descriptions. Taxonomists remain essential for refining the text, correcting errors, and adding expert knowledge to the species descriptions.

Additionally, the Principal Investigator (PI) and a master's student from the University of Puerto Rico at Mayagüez received hands-on training at NASA Marshall Space Flight Center on producing Depth from Defocus (DfD) images using Keyence Digital Microscopes. This training provided deeper insights into how depth maps are generated and enabled direct incorporation of DfD methods into Descriptron’s workflows. As a result, the software can measure both 2D and 3D arthropod structures using standard computer vision methods and these new DfD approaches.

In trial studies, Descriptron was applied to numerous insect specimens in the superfamily Psylloidea (jumping plant lice). It successfully automated the segmentation of forewing structures and generated preliminary species descriptions. Human experts then edited and validated these drafts. While refinement was required to address AI “hallucinations” (incorrect information produced by the model), the time saved was still substantial. These early tests highlight the software’s promise for large-scale biodiversity research.

Outcomes and Broader Impacts

- Accelerated Species Descriptions: By reducing the most time-consuming steps—specifically, repetitive measurements and meticulous text drafting—Descriptron shows potential for speeding up the formal documentation of undescribed species.
- Open-Source Tool: Making Descriptron widely available can empower a broad user base. Amateur naturalists, students, and scientists in under-resourced regions could employ it to describe new species from their local areas.
- Facilitated Training and Collaboration: The project has already sparked collaborations between computer scientists, taxonomists, and biodiversity specialists. The graphical user interface provides a user-friendly entry point, lowering barriers to advanced image- and text-processing methods.
- New Research Avenues in Evolutionary Biology: By integrating shape analysis, color segmentation, and AI-generated text within a single platform, Descriptron provides a framework for exploring automated taxonomy on other taxonomic groups—particularly so-called “dark taxa,” those with many undescribed species.

Product of This Grant
A detailed overview of the research, methods, and initial results is presented in a bioRxiv preprint:
Descriptron: Testing Artificial Intelligence for Automating Taxonomic Species Descriptions with a User-friendly Software Package
by Alex R. Van Dam and Liliya Štarhová Serbina
Link: [https://doi.org/10.1101/2025.01.07.631758](https://doi.org/10.1101/2025.01.07.631758)

This paper offers comprehensive technical details and guidance on implementing Descriptron for various types of morphological data.

Next Steps
Future developments will focus on:

- Improved Accuracy: Reducing errors and “hallucinations” by refining training data and prompting methods for the language model.
- Enhanced 3D Capabilities: Expanding beyond two-dimensional images to include 3D scanning and depth data, potentially enabling more precise measurements of complex structures.
- Broader Application: Testing Descriptron on different groups of plants, animals, or microorganisms to ensure its robustness across diverse biological materials.

Ultimately, the work supported by this grant contributes to a more efficient and inclusive taxonomic process. By easing technical burdens and automating meticulous morphological data collection needed for describing species, Descriptron can help scientists and citizen-scientists alike contribute to describing Earth’s biodiversity—thereby informing conservation strategies, ecosystem monitoring, and ongoing studies of life’s remarkable variety.
